item.title: llm4s.g8 – A Developer experience boost for LLM4S SDK (Issue #94)
item.description:
🎯 Background

llm4s: Github repo

In the rapidly evolving landscape of software development, where artificial intelligence and language models are reshaping how we build applications, the LLM4S SDK stands out as a powerful toolkit for Scala developers eager to harness the potential of large language models. However, as with many sophisticated tools, the initial onboarding experience can often feel like navigating a labyrinth without a map. This was precisely the challenge highlighted in Issue #94 on the llm4s GitHub repo :

item.title: My Road to Google Developer Expert (GDE): A hands-on guide from an Engineer who walked the path
item.description:
If you’re reading this, you’re probably thinking of applying for the Google Developer Expert (GDE) program - or at least curious what it takes. I’ve walked that path. This post is a no-BS breakdown of my journey, including what worked, what didn’t, and what surprised me along the way.

🧭 Why I Chose the GDE Path

For me, GDE wasn’t about a title - it was about recognizing and amplifying the work I was already doing. I’ve been in the engineering game for 12+ years - data pipelines, architecture, tooling, open source, mentoring - and the GDE program felt like a natural next step to formalize those contributions.

item.title: DQ Is Not Dairy Queen: Building My Own Data Quality Framework
item.description:
🍦 DQ ≠ Ice Cream

When someone hears “DQ Framework,” I get asked if it comes with sprinkles. It doesn’t. It comes with sanity-saving data validations, automatable quality checks, and opinionated constraints that don’t melt under pressure.

So no, this isn’t about Dairy Queen. But it does prevent frozen pipelines. ❄️

💡 Why I Built It

Every data engineer has been there:

  • A critical job runs on time… and writes garbage.
  • Downstream dashboards look suspiciously optimistic.
  • Stakeholders smile because they don’t know 18% of yesterday’s rows are NULL.

I couldn’t keep slapping WHERE col IS NOT NULL forever. So I built a reusable, testable Data Quality Framework ( DQF) and paired it with a Declarative Pipeline Assurance Tool (DPAT).

item.title: Scala Meets Data Engineering: Functional Tools I Wish Existed
item.description:
🔁 “I got tired of repeating myself. So I wrote Scala code that repeats me better than I do.”

Growing up in data engineering, I constantly saw the same patterns: filter, map, explode, transform—not once, but dozens of times across projects. I realized I needed tools that were like helpers on speed dial. Enter the Data Engineering Functional Extensions I built and shared on GitHub.

🚀 What’s In the Repo


🔗 View on GitHub: vim89/dataengineering-savvy

Inside, you’ll find:
